SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

uk.ac.cf.cs.scm5mjw.mda.devices
Class AbstractWirelessDevice

java.lang.Object
  uk.ac.cf.cs.scm5mjw.mda.devices.AbstractWirelessDevice
Direct Known Subclasses:
Beacon, InformationSource, MobileObject
public abstract class AbstractWirelessDevice
extends java.lang.Object

This is a class is a skeletal implementation of a supertype for all objects in the simulation which can communicate wirelessly.
The functionality which these objects have in common has been grouped into this class so as to reduce duplication.

Note that on creation, each device is given an immutable device ID number. These numbers are automatically assigned by this class and increment in the order that device are created. (For example, the first device created has the ID 1). Device IDs are unique across ALL devices (their subclass type is irrelevant).
Static method resetNextDeviceID will reset the device IDs to 1. Thus, IDs for devices created after a reset will start at 1. Users of this class should thus be careful as it means two devices may have the same ID.

Notes on units:
* Communication range is in meters
* Communication time (time remaining) is in seconds

Field Detail

DEFAULT_COMMUNICATION_RANGE

public static final double DEFAULT_COMMUNICATION_RANGE
See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

AbstractWirelessDevice

public AbstractWirelessDevice()
This constructor JUST sets up the default values of a wireless device. If a subclass overrides this constructor, it must be sure to call this constructor so that these initial variables are set up correctly.
This includes the set up of:
* Communication Range
* Initial communication session variables
* The artifact container

Method Detail

reaches

public boolean reaches(AbstractWirelessDevice dev)
This method checks whether the input AbstractWirelessDevice is in the communication range of this AbstractWirelessDevice, but NOT the other way around.
Thus, given two AbstractWirelessDevices a and b,
a.reaches( b )
will return true if b is within a's communication range. However, b does NOT necessarily need to be in a's communication range.

(Note that communication range is inclusive, thus an device that is exactly at another's communication range still counts as being in range.)

canCommunicateWith

public boolean canCommunicateWith(AbstractWirelessDevice dev)
This method checks whether this AbstractWirelessDevice and the inputted AbstractWirelessDevice can communicate. For two devices to communicate they both need to be within eachother's communication ranges.
Note that this method is NOT responsible for taking into account whether or not the devices are already communicating.
Thus, given two AbstractWirelessDevices a and b, this returns true if:
a.reaches( b ) AND b.reaches( a )

See Also:
reaches(AbstractWirelessDevice)

getCommunicationPhase

public CommunicationPhase getCommunicationPhase()
Accessor for the device's current communication phase. Only a communicating device has a communication phase.

Throws:
CommuicationException - if the device is not communicating
See Also:
isCommunicating()

getCommunicationTimeRemaining

public double getCommunicationTimeRemaining()
Accessor for the amount of communication time remaining. This is the amount of time remaining in the current phase of communication, not necessarily the whole communication.

Throws:
CommunicationException - if this device is not communicating

getCommunicationPartner

public AbstractWirelessDevice getCommunicationPartner()
Accessor for the current communication partner (the other device that this device is communicating with).

Throws:
CommunicationException - if this device is not communicating

isCommunicating

public boolean isCommunicating()
Accessor for whether or not this device is currently communicating.
Note that a device may still return true for this device even if the remaining time is 0. (It is assumed that once a device's remaining time reaches 0, a communication completion invocation should be made.)

getArtifactContainer

public ArtifactContainer getArtifactContainer()
Accessor for this device's ArtifactContainer (and hence the artifacts this device holds).

getArtifactsToCommit

public java.util.List<Artifact> getArtifactsToCommit()
The method returns the list of artifacts which are to be committed (if the communication session is a success).
This method will never return null. If no artifacts are to be transferred, then an empty list SHOULD be returned (this behaviour is enforced by the setCommunicationAttributes method and should be dealt with by the communication controller).

advanceCommunication

public void advanceCommunication(double timeIncrement)
Advance this device's communication by the given time.
This method will increment this device's attributes that vary with time by timeIncrement.
These attributes are:
- the age of the device's artifacts
- the time remaining in this device's communication session (if it is communicating)
Notes on communication time remaining:
- Only THIS device's time left is updated (the time left of the communication partner is unaffected).
- If all of the device's communication time elapses as a result of this advancement, the time remaining will be set to 0.

checkCommunication

public void checkCommunication()
This method will check to see if this device's communication needs to attempt discovery, complete or abort. If so, it will carry out the relevant action.

This will affect BOTH the devices involved in the communication.
This method MAY be called on a device that is not in a communication session. In this case, the method will simply have no affect.

The work of discovery / completion / abortion is actually deferred to the corresponding method if this class (e.g. attemptDiscovery), which is in turn deferred to this device's communication controller.

See Also:
attemptDiscovery(), abortCommunication()(), completeCommunication()

setInitiationPhase

public void setInitiationPhase(double duration,
                               AbstractWirelessDevice partner)
This method will set up this device's attributes (and only this device's attributes) for a communication session with another device. This will put the communication session in the first communication phase -- the initiation phase.
Essentially, this method sets up a communication session with another device.

Throws:
CommunicationException - if the devices cannot reach each other
CommunicationException - if THIS device is already in a communication session
CommunicationException - if the communication partner is this device
java.lang.NullPointerException - if the communication partner is the null reference
See Also:
setTransmissionPhase(double, List), unsetCommunicationAttributes()

setTransmissionPhase

public void setTransmissionPhase(double duration,
                                 java.util.List<Artifact> artifactsToAdd)
This method will move this device's communication session into the transmission phase and set up the attributes for this phase accordingly.
Again, note that this method will only affect THIS device in the communication session, not the partner.
A null value for artifactsToAdd will not be accepted. If there are no artifacts to transfer, then an empty list should be passed in.

Throws:
CommunicationException - if the device is not in a communication session
CommunicationException - if the devices cannot reach each other
CommunicationException - if the device is not currently in the initiation phase (on entry to this method)
CommunicationException - if the list of artifacts to be transferred is the null reference
See Also:
unsetCommunicationAttributes()

unsetCommunicationAttributes

public void unsetCommunicationAttributes()
This method will set the communication session attributes such that there is no communication session. The role of the method is to put the device into a state where it is not in a communication session, FROM a state where it WAS in a communication session.
Note that calling this method should not be called when a device is not in a communication session.
(Also note that this method will only affect THIS device -- no others.)
The affected attributes are:
- isCommunicating
- commPartner
- timeLeft
- artifactsToAdd
- commPhase

The value -1 is used for timeLeft when a device is not communicating (this should not matter, however, since isCommunication is the attribute to be used to indicate a communicating device).

commitArtifacts

public java.util.List<Artifact> commitArtifacts()
This method will commit the transfer (if any) of artifacts to this device. These are the artifacts that are to be added to this device on completion of communication.
Note that this will not handle unsetting the artifactsToAdd attribute.

The method returns the list of artifacts which were committed.
This method will never return null. If no artifacts were transferred, then an empty list SHOULD be returned (this behaviour is enforced by the setCommunicationAttributes method and should be dealt with by the communication controller).

initiateCommunication

public void initiateCommunication(AbstractWirelessDevice device)
Initiates a communication with another device.
The communication for BOTH devices (this device and the argument device) will be initiated. This is really an entry method which defers the actual (complicated) work of calculating and performing various operations for a communication to the Communication Controller for this class.

attemptDiscovery

public void attemptDiscovery()
At some point during the communication between devices, we need to model the process of attempting discovery. This method handles attempting discovery.
The discovery for BOTH devices in this communication will be attempted. This is really an entry method which defers the actual work of calculating and performing various operations for discovery to the Communication Controller for this class.

completeCommunication

public void completeCommunication()
This method will cause the communication that this node is currently involved in to be completed. Note that this will complete the communication for BOTH partners in the communication.
Communication completion is where actual changes to devices due to a communication are committed (because the communication time has fully elapsed with the device still in range).
A completed communication does not necessarily imply a successful communication. Transmission may still fail since we are modelling a transmission success rate in the communication completion.
This is really an entry method which defers the actual work of completing communication to the Communication Controller for this class.

abortCommunication

public void abortCommunication()
This method will cause the communication that this node is currently involved in to be aborted. Note that this will abort the communication for BOTH partners in the communication.
(An aborted communication means that the communication session is finished prematurely -- it does not manage to send any messages)

This is really an entry method which defers the actual work of aborting communication to the CommunicationController for this class.

getDeviceTypeIdentifier

public abstract java.lang.String getDeviceTypeIdentifier()
This method should return a textual string which identifies the type of device that this is. (e.g. a MobileDevice).
Other classes may use this when they want to get a textual name for the type of device.

getCommunicationController

public static CommunicationController getCommunicationController()
An accessor for the class's CommunicationController. Note that a communication controller exists for a class (and hence it is the same for all AbstractWirelessDevice objects).

setCommunicationController

public static void setCommunicationController(CommunicationController inCommController)
A mutator for the class's CommunicationController. Note that a communication controller exists for a class (and hence it is the same for all AbstractWirelessDevice objects).

resetNextDeviceID

public static void resetNextDeviceID()
This method will reset the next ID to 1.
IDs for devices created after a reset will start from 1 again.
